hints_html:
Using the solution of part (a), we calculate the integral

\(\displaystyle \int_{-1}^2\int_{x^2}^{x+2}\frac{\exp(x)}{2-x}\;\text{d}y\text{d}x\)

It make sense to use the order of integration, where we first integrate with respect to \(\displaystyle y\), since integration with respect to \(\displaystyle x\) first is very hard with this integrand.

After integration with respect to \(\displaystyle y\), you need to integrate

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \int_{-1}^{2}\frac{\exp(x)}{2 - x}\left(x + 2 - x^{2} \right)\text{d}x\end{aligned}\]

Factorize the term in the brackets, then use integration by parts.

hints_raw:
Using the solution of [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH200/April_2012/Question_06_(a)|part (a)]], we calculate the integral

<math>\displaystyle \int_{-1}^2\int_{x^2}^{x+2}\frac{\exp(x)}{2-x}\;\text{d}y\text{d}x</math>

It make sense to use the order of integration, where we first integrate with respect to <math>\displaystyle  y</math>, since integration with respect to <math>\displaystyle x</math> first is very hard with this integrand.
After integration with respect to <math> \displaystyle y </math>, you need to integrate

:<math>\displaystyle \int_{-1}^{2}\frac{\exp(x)}{2 - x}\left(x + 2 - x^{2} \right)\text{d}x</math>

Factorize the term in the brackets, then use integration by parts.
question: 6 (b)
sols_html:
Using our answer from part (a), we can write I with the given \(f\) as

\[\begin{aligned} I = \int_{-1}^{2}\int_{x^{2}}^{x + 2}\frac{\exp(x)}{2 - x}\,dydx.\end{aligned}\]

We can evaluate the integral as follows:

\[\begin{aligned} I &= \int_{-1}^{2}\int_{x^{2}}^{x + 2}\frac{\exp(x)}{2 - x}\,dydx \\ &= \int_{-1}^{2}\frac{\exp(x)}{2 - x}\left(x + 2 - x^{2} \right)\,dx \\ &= \int_{-1}^{2}\frac{\exp(x)}{2 - x}(-x + 2)(x + 1)\,dx \\ &= \int_{-1}^{2}\exp(x)(x + 1)\,dx.\end{aligned}\]

Using integration by parts, with u=x+1 and dv = exp(x),

\[\begin{aligned} I &= \int_{-1}^{2}\exp(x)(x + 1)\,dx \\ &= \exp(x)(x + 1)\Big\vert_{-1}^{2} - \int_{-1}^{2}\exp(x)\,dx \\ &= 3\exp(2) - \left(\exp(x)\Big\vert_{-1}^{2}\right) = 2\exp(2) + \exp(-1)\end{aligned}\]

Therefore,

\[\begin{aligned} {\color{blue}\int_{-1}^{2}\int_{x^{2}}^{x + 2}\frac{\exp(x)}{2 - x}\,dydx = 2e^{2} + e^{-1} }\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
Using our answer from [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH200/April_2012/Question_06_(a)|part (a)]], we can write <i>I</i> with the given ''&fnof;'' as
:<math>
I = \int_{-1}^{2}\int_{x^{2}}^{x + 2}\frac{\exp(x)}{2 - x}\,dydx.
</math>
We can evaluate the integral as follows:
:<math>
\begin{align}
I &= \int_{-1}^{2}\int_{x^{2}}^{x + 2}\frac{\exp(x)}{2 - x}\,dydx \\
&= \int_{-1}^{2}\frac{\exp(x)}{2 - x}\left(x + 2 - x^{2} \right)\,dx \\
&= \int_{-1}^{2}\frac{\exp(x)}{2 - x}(-x + 2)(x + 1)\,dx \\
&= \int_{-1}^{2}\exp(x)(x + 1)\,dx.
\end{align}
</math>
Using <b>integration by parts</b>, with ''u=x+1'' and ''dv = exp(x)'',
:<math>
\begin{align}
I &= \int_{-1}^{2}\exp(x)(x + 1)\,dx \\
&= \exp(x)(x + 1)\Big\vert_{-1}^{2} - \int_{-1}^{2}\exp(x)\,dx \\
&= 3\exp(2) - \left(\exp(x)\Big\vert_{-1}^{2}\right) = 2\exp(2) + \exp(-1)
\end{align}
</math>
Therefore,
:<math>
{\color{blue}
\int_{-1}^{2}\int_{x^{2}}^{x + 2}\frac{\exp(x)}{2 - x}\,dydx = 2e^{2} + e^{-1}
}
</math>
